body:
I already told you, that's what past me thinks too. Something always did feel a bit off but I never questioned it and dismissed any claim to the contrary as progressive quackery on reflex, as I had been trained to do. That was until I actually saw it with my own eyes.

Leviticus 18:22 and 20:13 do not say, "You shall not lie with a male as one lies with a female; it is an abomination", but, "And with a male you shall not lie lyings of a woman; it is an abomination". וְאֶ֨ת־זָכָ֔ר לֹ֥א תִשְׁכַּ֖ב מִשְׁכְּבֵ֣י אִשָּׁ֑ה תֹּועֵבָ֖ה הִֽוא And "lying" used as a noun, as it is here, almost always means *bed*, which the LXX, the earliest known translation, recognizes. Moreover, the language used here is unlike anything else used to describe sexual relations.

That's the only "proof text" in a source actually given by God. And beyond that this book itself is corrupt (Jeremiah 8:8). Have you seen some of the crazy laws in there? And notice how true believers and Jesus himself didn't follow them. But people are selfish and cultish, and the urge to condemn others for the benefit of you and your tribe is ever-present. But the non-Jewish adopters also didn't like all the laws, just some of them. So they came up with a ridiculous excuse that, instead of just following Jesus's golden rule, invented "dispensationalism" and "fulfillment of the law" which allows them to pick and choose which laws they like and don't like.

body:
Like I said,  I've heard this more than a few times before,  and read more than a few rebuttals to this line of logic (None of which are apparently promoted in Google's search results any longer... *interesting* that.  I'll try to find links to them to when I don't have obligations pressing on my time. )

Absent those, I'll suggest a couple points to consider. 


-Nowhere in the Bible is there an example of condoned homosexuality. 

- There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament,  all implying it is sinful. 

Obfuscation by a handful of *progressive, revisionist* scholars to subvert the simple intent of the law doesn't hold much weight IMO.

In the end,  the context makes it most clear.  A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality. 

When I was younger,  I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with,  but I grew out of that phase.   Now I understand that our father's  rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins,  not proudly declare we did nothing wrong. 

Oh yeah,  and to love and forgive our brothers and sisters no matter what.  77 times if we have to.  

As I said earlier,  and I maintain now again: I do not condemn God's gay children, my own sins are enough for me to worry about.   I abhore legalism and embrace grace, praise God. 

***I did find an interesting rebuttal I read on Quora from a Hebrew translator.  It is the first response to this thread https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-specific-meaning-of-Leviticus-20-13

"You make some interesting points. However, I think there are a few points you are missing about the Hebrew text.

The verb used is a direct verb (“את זכר לא תשכב”) unlike the verbs used in both English and modern Hebrew which are indirect as in “sleep with”. This is significant in that it shows a totally different concept of what sex is. In the Bible sex is something that a man does to someone else, usually a woman. That is why adultery in the ten commandments is sleeping with another man’s wife, and why nothing is ever said (until the Talmud) about Lesbians — women don’t do sex, they have sex done to them.

So the phrase is obviously directed at the male reader and directs him not to sleep with a male. If that was the extent of the verse, it would be quite clear. But then they had to go and qualify this with the “משכבי אישה”.

The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:

Don’t f--k a man
Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman
OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."

body:
> There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament, all implying it is sinful.

Sodom & Gomorrah doesn't even comment about it, nor does Ham's story, nor are either of these God's words. We're left with 2 supposed references by Paul in his actual letters, which are also not God's words. One is almost certainly incorrect, the other (Romans 1) is still uncertain, was probably added later, *and* it's part of a larger passage which is likely Paul quoting someone else judging by the way chapter 2 starts. The others are 1 Timothy, which is also very unlikely to be correct, and also not actually written by Paul. The last supposed one is Jude, which is also not God's own words; and it says "different flesh" not "homo", because if you recall the Sodomites were trying to rape the angels. The whole Jude passage is about angels too.

> In the end, the context makes it most clear. Like I said,  I've heard this more than a few times before,  and read more than a few rebuttals to this line of logic (None of which are apparently promoted in Google's search results any longer... *interesting* that.  I'll try to find links to them to when I don't have obligations pressing on my time. )

Absent those, I'll suggest a couple points to consider. 


-Nowhere in the Bible is there an example of condoned homosexuality. 

- There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament,  all implying it is sinful. 

Obfuscation by a handful of *progressive, revisionist* scholars to subvert the simple intent of the law doesn't hold much weight IMO.

In the end,  the context makes it most clear.  A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality. 

When I was younger,  I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with,  but I grew out of that phase.   Now I understand that our father's  rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins,  not proudly declare we did nothing wrong. 

Oh yeah,  and to love and forgive our brothers and sisters no matter what.  77 times if we have to.  

As I said earlier,  and I maintain now again: I do not condemn God's gay children, my own sins are enough for me to worry about.   I abhore legalism and embrace grace, praise God. 

***I did find an interesting rebuttal I read on Quora from a Hebrew translator.  It is the first response to this thread https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-specific-meaning-of-Leviticus-20-13

"You make some interesting points. However, I think there are a few points you are missing about the Hebrew text.

The verb used is a direct verb (“את זכר לא תשכב”) unlike the verbs used in both English and modern Hebrew which are indirect as in “sleep with”. This is significant in that it shows a totally different concept of what sex is. In the Bible sex is something that a man does to someone else, usually a woman. That is why adultery in the ten commandments is sleeping with another man’s wife, and why nothing is ever said (until the Talmud) about Lesbians — women don’t do sex, they have sex done to them.

So the phrase is obviously directed at the male reader and directs him not to sleep with a male. If that was the extent of the verse, it would be quite clear. But then they had to go and qualify this with the “משכבי אישה”.

The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:

Don’t f--k a man
Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman
OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."

body: It seems like you're looking at the text having already decided what the meaning is. In reality it's literally "And with a male you shall not lie beds of a woman". Nothing more or less, that's what it says, and the lack of a linking word between lie and beds is not a typo. The Septuagint, the earliest translation, renders it this way, indicating that's how it was understood. There are plenty of sexual condemnations in that chapter but no other instance describing sexual intercourse in the *entire Bible* uses the words of this one. The only reason it seems obvious to you is because of your culture and the current controversy over that particular issue. It's at the front of your mind, and you see false positives. Someone who'd never heard of this before would not get the same impression as you do.
